title: Mandaluyong
text:
', officially the ' (), is a <a href="Cities%20of%20the%20Philippines%23Legal%20classification"></a> in the of the . According to the , it has a population of people.
Located directly east of <a href="Manila">Manila</a>, it is known for the <a href="Ortigas%20Center">Ortigas Center</a>, a commercial and business center that is also shared with the city of <a href="Pasig">Pasig</a>. Notable institutions and establishments in the city include the <a href="Asian%20Development%20Bank">Asian Development Bank</a>, the headquarters of <a href="Banco%20De%20Oro">Banco De Oro</a> and <a href="San%20Miguel%20Corporation">San Miguel Corporation</a> and shopping malls like <a href="Shangri-La%20Plaza">Shangri-La Plaza</a> and <a href="SM%20Megamall">SM Megamall</a>.
The city is bordered by <a href="Manila">Manila</a> to the west, <a href="San%20Juan%2C%20Metro%20Manila">San Juan</a> to the north, <a href="Quezon%20City">Quezon City</a> to the northeast, <a href="Pasig">Pasig</a> to the east, and <a href="Makati">Makati</a> to the south. It is also the <a href="List%20of%20cities%20in%20the%20Philippines%23List">6th-smallest city</a> in the Philippines with a land area of , similar to <a href="Makati">Makati</a> and <a href="Marikina">Marikina</a>
Etymology.
There are different stories on the origin of the name "Mandaluyong".
One tells of how the place was abundant with a kind of tree called "luyong", now more commonly known as "anahaw" ("<a href="Saribus%20rotundifolius">Saribus rotundifolius</a>"), from which canes and furniture were made.
Another claims that the Spaniards named the place based on the report of a navigator named Acapulco, who saw the rolling hills frequently being lashed at by "daluyong" (“big waves from the sea”). This seems to confirm traditional pre-Hispanic stories that giant waves from the sea would meet the adjoining hills of the vast lowland, referred to as "salpukan ng alon". Felix dela Huerta, a <a href="Franciscan">Franciscan</a> historian, observed that the rolling topography of this land resembled giant waves of the sea.
As with the etymological legends of many Philippine places, when the foreigners asked what the place was called, the locals answered with the description "madaluyong" ("undulating"), later transcribed by Spanish writers as "Mandaluyong," with the addition of an “n”.
Another version of the name is based on a legend that a <a href="Maharlika">Maharlika</a> named Luyong fell in love with Manda, the lovely daughter of a <a href="barangay">barangay</a> chieftain. The chieftain did not like Luyong and forbade him Manda's hand. Luyong overcame this objection by winning a series of tribal contests, as was the custom at the time. The couple settled thereafter in a place which was later called “Mandaluyong" - a term made up of <a href="portmanteau">joining their names</a>.
History.
14th century.
Residents of Mandaluyong have always been known for their industry. Men did the laundry to the amusement of non-residents until shortly after the war, while the women ironed the clothes.
These industrious people trace their roots to Emperor Soledan (also known as “Anka Widyaya” of the Great Madjapahit Empire) and Empress Sasaban of the <a href="Namayan">Kingdom of Sapa</a>, whose son Prince Balagtas ruled as sovereign of the kingdom in about the year 1300.
More than a century later, in about the year 1470, it expanded and was called the “<a href="Namayan">Kingdom of Namayan</a>” with “Lakan Takhan” as sovereign. The vast Kingdom comprised what are now <a href="Quiapo%2C%20Manila">Quiapo</a>, <a href="San%20Miguel%2C%20Manila">San Miguel</a>, <a href="Santa%20Mesa%2C%20Manila">Sta, Mesa</a>, <a href="Paco%2C%20Manila">Paco</a>, <a href="Pandacan">Pandacan</a>, Malate, <a href="Manila">Malate</a> and <a href="Santa%20Ana%2C%20Manila">Santa Ana</a> in <a href="Manila">Manila</a>, and Mandaluyong, <a href="San%20Juan%2C%20Metro%20Manila">San Juan</a>, <a href="Makati">Makati</a>, <a href="Pasay">Pasay</a>, <a href="Pateros">Pateros</a>, <a href="Taguig">Taguig</a>, <a href="Para%C3%B1aque">Parañaque</a>, and portions of <a href="Pasig">Pasig</a> and <a href="Quezon%20City">Quezon City</a> up to <a href="Diliman">Diliman</a>, which were then part of Mandaluyong.
19th century.
Mandaluyong was first known as a barrio of Santa Ana de Sapa, which was part of the District of Paco, Province of Tondo. Named San Felipe Neri by the Spaniards in honor of the patron saint of <a href="Rome">Rome</a>, it was separated civilly from Santa Ana de Sapa in 1841.
On 15 September 1863 <a href="St.%20Philip%20Neri">San Felipe Neri</a> established its own parish. Under the administration of the Congregation “Dulcísimo Nombre de Jesús”, it constructed its own church, convent and school. The Parish of San Felipe Neri played a significant role as a relay station for propagating the Katipunan during the 1896–1898 Revolution.
Mandaluyong was significant in the <a href="Philippine%20Revolution">Philippine Revolution</a> of 1896 as the baluarte (territory) of the Katipunan or "Makabuhay" group, with seventeen branches.
On 29 August 1896, <a href="Andres%20Bonifacio">Andres Bonifacio</a>, together with <a href="Emilio%20Jacinto">Emilio Jacinto</a> and other members of the <a href="Katipunan">Katipunan</a> went into the house of Romualdo Vicencio at Sitio Balakbak (now Villa San Miguel) to prepare for the upcoming revolution against Spanish authority. In this site, Bonifacio read the last manifestation of the Katipunan before they transferred in Hagdan Bato, in the house of Felix Sanchez. This event is also known as the "29 De Agosto" and "Pinagtipunan" in which it is already named in two streets near the historic Barangay Hagdan Bato Itaas. It was in Barangay Hagdang Bato on 28 August 1896 where Andres Bonifacion issued a proclamation setting Saturday, 29 August 1896 as the date of the attack on Manila.
On 30 August 1896, after the successfully revolution in San Felipe Neri, the katipuneros went to San Juan del Monte and attacked the El Polvorin (gunpowder depot) in order to amass more weapons to use against the Spaniards. This event is popularly known as the <a href="Battle%20of%20San%20Juan%20del%20Monte">Battle of San Juan del Monte</a>.
It was also in this town that the revolutionary paper, “La Republika”, was established on 15 September 1896.
20th century.
During the <a href="American%20Colonial%20Period%20%28Philippines%29">American Occupation</a>, San Felipe Neri was raised to a first class municipality with five barrios, namely: Poblacion, Barangka, Hagdang Bato, Namayan and Hulo. Under Presidential Act No. 942, it was consolidated with the municipality of <a href="San%20Juan%2C%20Metro%20Manila">San Juan del Monte</a> and became the seat of government. For several months in 1904, San Felipe Neri became the capital of the province of <a href="Rizal%20Province">Rizal</a>.
San Felipe Neri was separated from San Juan and became an independent municipality on 27 March 1907. It was renamed the Municipality of Mandaluyong by virtue of House Bill No. 3836 which was authored and sponsored by Assemblyman Pedro Magsalin, then the Representative of the District of Rizal. Many government infrastructures are established during the American Period including the Correctional Institute for Women, Welfareville Compound, The Boy's Town, and the <a href="National%20Center%20for%20Mental%20Health">National Center for Mental Health</a>.
During <a href="World%20War%20II">World War II</a>, Mandaluyong lost many of her people; among them were Catholic priests and civilians. Destruction was felt all over, but with the timely arrival of the American Liberation Forces and the Philippine Commonwealth troops on 9 February 1945, the municipality was saved from further damages. That day became a red calendar day for Mandaluyong marking its liberation from the Japanese Imperial forces by the Allies.
After World War II, Mandaluyong began to become progressive and dramatically increase the economy. Many infrastructures, companies, and other businesses were developed in 1950s–1960s and as the result, Mandaluyong recognized as the most developed municipality in the Province of Rizal.
Separation from Rizal province.
On 7 November 1975, Mandaluyong was formally included in newly established Metropolitan Manila by virtue of Presidential Decree No. 824 signed by President <a href="Ferdinand%20Marcos">Ferdinand Marcos</a>.
By virture of the 1987 Constitution Mandaluyong and the then municipality of San Juan were represented in congress by a single Congressman.
Cityhood.
Rep. Ronaldo Zamora sponsored a House Bill which eventually became Republic Act No. 7675 otherwise known as "An Act Converting the Municipality of Mandaluyong into a Highly Urbanized City to be known as the City of Mandaluyong." President <a href="Fidel%20Ramos">Fidel V. Ramos</a> signed R.A. No. 7675 into law on 9 February 1994 (the 49th anniversary of its liberation from the Japanese), which was ratified through a plebiscite on 10 April 1994 making Mandaluyong the 5th city in <a href="Metro%20Manila">Metro Manila</a>. Mandaluyong became a lone district with its own Representative in Congress. Prior to the enactment of the assailed statute, the municipalities of Mandaluyong and San Juan belonged to only one legislative district.
21st century.
Mandaluyong today is composed of 27 barangays divided into two political districts mainly by Boni Avenue and G. Aglipay Street. As of 9 January 2002, it has 1,238 voting precincts and 166,037 registered voters.
In 2003, Mandaluyong was recognized as "The Tiger City of the Philippines" because of dramatic improvement in the city's economy.
History of local barrios.
According to Pedro Patricio in his book (Mandaluyong: 1837–1975), Mandaluyong had five original barrios (Poblacion, Barangka, Hagdang Bato, Namayan, & Hulo) as per the first recorded census in 1903. From these five evolved 22 sub-barrios.
Geography.
Mandaluyong lies on a heart-shaped of land, southeast of Manila and west of Pasig. To the south lies Makati, to the northwest, San Juan, and to the northeast, Quezon City. Thus Mandaluyong is located at the center of Metro Manila.
Barangays.
Mandaluyong is politically subdivided into 27 <a href="barangays">barangays</a>.
Climate.
Mandaluyong's climate is classified as tropical. In winter, there is much less rainfall in Mandaluyong than in summer. This climate is considered to be Aw according to the Köppen-Geiger climate classification. The temperature here averages 27.2 °C. In a year, the average rainfall is 2093 mm. Precipitation is the lowest in February, with an average of 8 mm. With an average of 448 mm, the most precipitation falls in August. At an average temperature of 29.2 °C, May is the hottest month of the year. January has the lowest average temperature of the year. It is 25.5 °C. Between the driest and wettest months, the difference in precipitation is 440 mm. During the year, the average temperatures vary by 3.7 °C.
Economy.
The city is home to a number of shopping centers, entertainment hubs, commercial establishments, high-rise offices, residential condominiums and hotels. The city is one of the important business and financial areas in the metropolis.
Commercial activities.
Like other cities in <a href="Metro%20Manila">Metro Manila</a>, Mandaluyong has its own share of commercial strips and a central business district.
The former commercial area, consisting mostly of banks, offices and service establishments, stretch along public transport routes thereby serving both local consumers and passers-by from the neighboring localities.
Major commercial strips of the city include the stretch of <a href="Boni%20Avenue">Boni Avenue</a>, <a href="Shaw%20Boulevard">Shaw Boulevard</a>, Libertad-Sierra Madre area, Kalentong, San Francisco, part of Martinez, Sgt. Bumatay towards Barangka Drive and Pinatubo towards <a href="EDSA">EDSA</a>. Mandaluyong's central business district is concentrated on the EDSA-Shaw-Pioneer area.
Industrial activities.
Industrial activities are mostly concentrated within the <a href="Shaw%20Boulevard">Shaw Boulevard</a>-<a href="Pioneer%20Street">Pioneer area</a> and along the <a href="Pasig%20River">Pasig River</a>. Although prominent in the manufacture of foods, medicines and laboratory equipment, these industries are gradually declining in number, opting to relocate in newly developed industrial zones outside Metropolitan Manila. In the <a href="Pasig%20River">Pasig River</a> area, particularly in Barangays Namayan and Mabini J. Rizal, areas formerly industrial are now the sites for residential subdivisions and townhouses. In the EDSA-Shaw-Pioneer area, the transformation is toward a more economically profitable and globally competitive commercial activity. And since December 2013, Mandaluyong is the home of one of the largest television networks in the country <a href="TV5%20%28Philippine%20TV%20network%29">TV5</a> and one of the largest pay TV operator <a href="Cignal%20TV">Cignal TV</a> (both owned by the <a href="PLDT">PLDT</a>-backed firm <a href="MediaQuest%20Holdings">MediaQuest Holdings</a> located at the <a href="TV5%20Media%20Center">TV5 Media Center</a>), <a href="Nine%20Media%20Corporation">Nine Media Corporation</a>-owned news channel <a href="CNN%20Philippines">CNN Philippines</a> and the master playout facility of <a href="Solar%20Entertainment%20Corporation">Solar Entertainment Corporation</a> (both are located at the Worldwide Corporate Center which also housed the main offices of <a href="Vista%20Land">companies</a> owned by real estate magnate and former Senator <a href="Manny%20Villar">Manny Villar</a>), and several radio stations associated to the Vera Group (<a href="DWLL">Mellow 94.7</a>, <a href="DWTM">Magic 89.9</a>, <a href="DWRT-FM">99.5 Play FM</a>, <a href="DWKX">103.5 K-Lite</a>, <a href="DWBL">DWBL</a> and <a href="DWSS-AM">DWSS</a>, all are located at the Paragon Plaza).
Shopping centers.
These super-regional supermalls each have over a hundred local and international stores and are anchored by at least one department store and supermarket or hypermarket. They are also the largest malls in Metro Manila which feature not just stores but also attractions: movie theaters, rides, skating rinks, bowling alleys and other recreational facilities. Each provides thousands of automobile parking spaces and are located mostly near <a href="List%20of%20Manila%20LRT%20and%20MRT%20stations">rail stations</a> and established <a href="business%20district">business district</a>s within the metropolis. These malls serve not only the Metro Manila and Greater Manila Area residents, but also local and foreign tourists. Among the malls in the city are <a href="Shangri-La%20Plaza%20Mall">Shangri-La Plaza</a> and <a href="SM%20Megamall">SM Megamall</a>.

Transportation.
The city is provided with good access roads to and from adjacent cities in the metropolis. The city is served by one of <a href="Metro%20Manila">Metro Manila</a>'s main roads such as the <a href="Epifanio%20de%20los%20Santos%20Avenue">Epifanio de los Santos Avenue</a> (EDSA), <a href="Ortigas%20Avenue">Ortigas Avenue</a> and <a href="Shaw%20Boulevard">Shaw Boulevard</a>.
Airport.
The city is 36 minutes away from the <a href="Ninoy%20Aquino%20International%20Airport">Ninoy Aquino International Airport</a>.
Land.
Mandaluyong is served by the <a href="Epifanio%20de%20los%20Santos%20Avenue">Epifanio de los Santos Avenue</a>, Metro Manila's main thoroughfare. Considered as the heart of the metropolis, main roads such as the <a href="Ortigas%20Avenue">Ortigas Avenue</a> and <a href="Shaw%20Boulevard">Shaw Boulevard</a> provide inter-city linkages, while <a href="Boni%20Avenue">Boni Avenue</a> and Martinez Street (C-3 Road) serve as alternate routes in the city. Other major roads in Mandaluyong include Boni-Pioneer Underpass, a 280-meter long tunnel underneath EDSA (Epifanio de los Santos Avenue) connecting Boni Avenue on its western-end and <a href="Pioneer%20Street">Pioneer Street</a> on the east. and <a href="Julia%20Vargas%20Avenue">Julia Vargas Avenue</a>. <a href="Jeepney">Jeepney</a>s are one of the most common modes of public transportation for commuters in the city. Aside from jeepneys, tricycles and pedicabs are also one of the important modes of public transportation in Mandaluyong, especially on alleys around the city.
Water.
The presence of the <a href="Pasig%20River">Pasig River</a> stretching along the south border of Mandaluyong provides an alternative route and mode of public transportation mainly for cargo freight of industries along the river, and for commuters seeking for a faster and more direct route to and from the cities of <a href="Pasig">Pasig</a> and <a href="Manila">Manila</a>. The <a href="Pasig%20River%20Ferry%20Service">Pasig River Ferry Service</a> has one station in the city.
Railway.
The city is also served by rail via the <a href="Manila%20Metro%20Rail%20Transit%20System%20Line%203">Manila Metro Rail Transit System Line 3</a>. The line is located along the Epifanio de los Santos Avenue. The city is served by three Line 3 stations:

Health.
Mandaluyong has several private and public hospitals & health center, namely the privately owned Dr. Victor R. Potenciano Medical Center along EDSA and Unciano General Hospital, and the government hospital Mandaluyong City Medical Center. The city is also home to the <a href="National%20Center%20for%20Mental%20Health">National Center for Mental Health</a>. Many residents, specifically the middle-to-upper class medical clientele, visit the nearby <a href="The%20Medical%20City">The Medical City</a> in Ortigas Center.
The Dr. Victor R. Potenciano Medical Center is a tertiary care hospital that has a 189-bed capacity within its 10-storey hospital building.
In 2007, the Mandaluyong city government, together with <a href="non-governmental%20organization">non-governmental organization</a> Rehabilitation and Empowerment of Adults and Children (REACH) Foundation, established a <a href="community-based%20rehabilitation">community-based rehabilitation</a> program called Project Therapy, Education, and Assimilation of Children with Handicap (TEACH), that caters to children with special needs coming from indigent families. Services given by Project TEACH include free <a href="occupational%20therapy">occupational therapy</a>, <a href="physical%20therapy">physical therapy</a>, <a href="speech%E2%80%93language%20pathology">speech therapy</a> and <a href="special%20education">special education</a> classes.
Education.
Four well-known educational institutions in the city are the <a href="Arellano%20University">Arellano University, Mandaluyong (Plaridel Campus)</a>, <a href="Don%20Bosco%20Technical%20College">Don Bosco Technical College</a>, <a href="Jose%20Rizal%20University">Jose Rizal University</a> and <a href="Rizal%20Technological%20University">Rizal Technological University</a>.
A good number of city officials of Mandaluyong are alumni of Don Bosco, including incumbent Mayor, <a href="Benjamin%20Abalos%20Jr.">Benjamin Abalos Jr.</a> (HS '79); former Vice Mayor, Renato Santa Maria (HS '65); City Councilors Edward Bartolome (HS '96), Noel Bernardo (HS '79), and Jonathan Abalos (HS '85). Other notable alumni include "King of Pinoy Rap," <a href="Francis%20Magalona">Francis Magalona</a> (HS '81); and actor <a href="Ricky%20Davao">Ricky Davao</a> (HS '78). Meanwhile, the alumni of JRU that includes President <a href="Ramon%20Magsaysay">Ramon Magsaysay</a>, Roderick Paulate, and Secretary Armand V. Fabella; 
Other colleges in the city include the Our Lady of Guadalupe Colleges (specializing in Medicine and Nursing), STI and AMA (both specializing in Computer Technology education, both located on Shaw Boulevard), NAMEI Polytechnic Institute (specializing in Marine Sciences), and the International Baptist College.
The city is also home to Lourdes School of Mandaluyong (est. 1959), a <a href="Franciscan">Franciscan</a>-Marian all-boys school, located in the <a href="Ortigas%20Center">Ortigas Center</a> district managed by the <a href="OFM%20Capuchins">OFM Capuchins</a>; <a href="La%20Salle%20Green%20Hills">La Salle Green Hills</a> (est. 1959), a private all-boys high school, managed by the <a href="De%20La%20Salle%20Brothers">De La Salle Brothers</a>, located along Ortigas Avenue; and <a href="Saint%20Pedro%20Poveda%20College">Saint Pedro Poveda College</a> (est. 1960), another all-girls institution, offering pre-school, grade school, high school, and college education. Although the official school address is Quezon City, part of the lot Poveda's campus stands on is under Mandaluyong.
<a href="Mandaluyong%20High%20School">Mandaluyong High School</a> (est. 1977) is the oldest public high school in the city. <a href="City%20of%20Mandaluyong%20Science%20High%20School">City of Mandaluyong Science High School</a> (est. 1996), a public science high school on E. Pantaleon St. The city has 18 public schools, including primary and secondary schools as prioritize by the city government. The Mataas Na Paaralang Nepatli A. Gonzales is the largest school in Mandaluyong and the only school in the city which has the STEM highschool program. The Neptalians are also multi- awarded and has various great observations by the regional supervisors that captures their attentions.
